THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: AMERIOA'S INCREASING TMPO RTS.
div.p: The following criticism in “Daons’ Jnterna- tional Review” for October fully accounts for the financial hurricane which has passed over the United States ; it reveals a veritable Rake’s. Progress, “but the actual condition was not fully guaged when the. article was written.

Imports of merchandise continue to provide the striking features of the foreign commerce if the United States, increasing so rapidly that the total for eight months of the calendar year 1907 exceeds a billion dollars in value, whereas it wax but a few years ago that the total for twelve months attained that figure. While the increase in imports bas been most striking in the latest comparison, it is found that expansion has been eteady for many years. Thus, the total for August, 1907, was $125,792,156, or over $20,000,000 more than in the same month last year, while that ex- ceeded August, 1907, by $10,000,000, and the gains for the three precedipg years averaged sbout $5,000,000. For five years the value of merchandise imported into the United States in. the month of Angust has risen trom 378,923,281 to the phenomenal total mention- “above, or about 60 per cent. The mid- summer months are not normally months of maximem foreign commerce by any means, and it is found that fiveofthe preceding eight months reported a slightly heavier total of imports, but no month prior to December, 1906, even appioximated the aggregate for last month.

The movement of exports has shown no such tendency to expand, but, on the contrary, the total of $127,625,508 in August, 1907, was about $2,000,0C0 less than in the same month last year, and is swaller than any of the intervening mOnths. In the méantime this country is falling behind as to its international trade balance, the decline im exports and marvelous expansion in imports bringing the movement +t merchandise so near an equili- briuim that practically nothing is left to settle the many intangible balances. In August exports exceeded imports only $1,833,852, to which may be added a net ontgo of gold aud silver amounting to $3,470,307, or a total on all aconunts of scarcely more than $5,000,000. This, obviously, will not begin to pay for lreight and insurance alone ; to say nothing of the money sent home by immigrants, expended by American tourists, required to pay dividends on American securities beld abroa/, and all the minor items which are invariably against the United States. There is one distinetly favorable fact that may be mentioned in this coumection, namely, that the New York market is Hot indebted to London and continental banke tor large advances through sales of bills in the foreign exchange market, as was the case a year ago. This is not due, by any means, to any indisposition on the part of America to borrow the money, but foreign capitalists have needed funds at home, and also felt some relactance about advance to this country, partly in view of the crop wneertainty which did not promise to provide the customary supply of commercial bills for settlement, and also to some extent on account of unsettled confidence by the ex- tensive decline that occurred in American securities. In this respect the situation has began to show distinct signs df improvement, and with the growth of. confidence there will probably be a tendency to inéfeasé loans of this nature. But itis fortunate at the present time when the merchandise balance is no help in making settlements, that these temporary loans have been transferred to banks in the United States, as is shown by the last statement of the Jontroller of the Corrency in which the na- tional banks alone increased loans and dis counts during the pxst year by $379,600,000 in the face of liyuidation in Wall Street and some contraction in other domestic depart- ments.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Beggare in Cairo. Ten beggars were arrested and fined in Cairo during the month of October.
Al Hayat
The A] Hayat Sanatorium at Helouan has been re-opened for the season.
The Late Princess Hanem,
The Khedivial Court will wear mourning for the late Princess Hanem for 40 days.
Hotel d’Angteterre.
The Hotel d’Angleterre will be re opened for the season on the 15th inst. under the manage- ment of Mr. Herrling.
Medjaz Railway.
Saady Bey Beshara al-Tahawi has subscribed LEB. 100to the Hedjaz Railway and handed this a.m to Ghazi Abined Mukbtar Pasha.
Traneport ‘‘Piassy”.
The British transport “Plassy” arrived at Port ‘Said yesterday homeward bound from India and proceeded again the same afternoon,
The Meooa Pligrimage.
The Khedive has ordered the appointment of Ibrahim Pasha Rifsat as Emir el Hag and Mohamed Bey Ali as treasurer of the pilgrimage funds.
Quarantine.

Afrivals in'Torkish ports from Beyrout are subjected to medical inspection, owing to the suspected case of plague which we reported to have been notified in the latter town. Similar regulations are also imposed against Adalin.
Bubonio Plague.
From the Ist of January to the 10th Nowem- ber 1907 there have been 1140 cases of bubonic plague under treatment, of which 848 have proved fatal. There are at present five cases under treatment.
Birthe and Deaths.

From the 29th of October to the 4th of November, 685 births and 332 deaths were recorded in Cairo. 12 European births and 9 deaths being incladed in these nambers. There were eleven fatal cases of diptheria, five of typhua, two of typhoid and one of small pox.
Provinotal Councils,

The Modirs of the Kalioubieb, Dakahlieh, and Sharkieh provincesare convening meetings for the purpose of examinirg the work to be ubdertaken next year. The meeting for the Kalioubieh province will be held at 19 am. on the 20th inat. that of Dakablieh at 10 a.m. on the 23rd inst. and of Sharkieh at 10 a.m. on the 26th inst.
Creek Visitors te Sinai.

Our Suez correspondent writes under yester- day's date :—His Beatitude Archbishop Por- phirios of Mount Sinai, accompanied by the Hellenic ex- Minister of Education, M. Papami- chailopoulos, left Suez this afternoon by the Kbedivial Mail liver “Missir’ for Tor, en route to Mount Sinai, where M Papamichailopoulos will complete a very interesting book on Mount Sinai archaeology, which he had begun on his previoue visit to Sinai in 1907. Shortly after the grand mass on St. Catherine’s day, in the Church of St Catherine at Mount Sinai, his Beatitude the Archbishop will return to bis residence in Cairo, while the ex-Minister will proceed to Athens.
Alexandria Amateur Theatricais.

It being the intention to form in Alexandria an amateur dramatic and musical society, whose object will be to stage comic operas, mysical comedies; and sketches and provide other eutertainments of a musical nature, all desirous of becoming members of sucha society are rejuested to send in their names and addresses to the Hon. Sec. pro. tem. c/o “Eyyp- tian’ Gazette,” E.V. Answers to this invitation should be sentin as early as possible, it being the intention of the promoters to give an euter- tainment early in the sexson. Applications are invited from all and itis hoped that readers of the “Egyptian Gazette” will accept this asen inducement to promote profitable entertain- ment in this city, and accordingly not hesitate to express their desire to join such a stiety as is hereby proposed. It is proposed that the profits uf every entertaipment should be devoted to local charities, irrespective of nationality, and to be selected by the com mittee, which will be appointed by the first general meeting, to be convened or receipt of a sufficient nomber of names to guarantee the success of such a society. The intention of the prombters of the society is that it should be formed for the support of local charities and for the promotion of amate r talent. Those who have taken part in earlier amateur per- formances are especially urged to send in their names.

div.head: FINANCIAL NOTES.
THE CASSA DI SCONTO.
div.p: The liquidation of the Cassa di Sconto of Alexandria which Suspended in June is re- ported to be making tavourable progress. About 40% ot the sssets have so far been already realised, and after the completion of the har- vest further sums will come in. It seems certain that the creditors will be paid in full, and that the shareholders will save a considerable part of their capital. The shares which had fallen to Fr. 19 have therefore secovered to Fr. 67. It is, indeed, expected to see them return to par. Plans are being prepared to form a new bank to take over all assets.
BOURSE AND BANKING.

At the request of Mr. Devonshire who has been retained on behalf of the above Company, Mr Gooding this morning made an application to the the British Consul General for the post- ponement of theappiication for the appointment of an Offcial Liquidator of the Company. An adjournment was granted for the 19th inst. We understand that Mr Devonshire intends to question the Jurisdiction of the British Con- sular Court.
GREEK CURRANT MONOPOLY.

The report of the Société Privilégiée pour Favoriser la Production et le Commerce du Raisin de Corinthe to hand is a satisfactory one The net profits for the year are 1,426,000 drachmai, of which sum the Directors propose to distribute a 6 per cent dividend of 15 frances per share, which will absorb 1,308,000 drachmai, the balance falling to the State, partly by tax and stamp duty and partly in virtue of Article 9 of the Company's charter. As this is only the second year of the monopoly, and as the great difficulty encountered im the opposition of the Eglish grocers owing to the en price Ot currants bas been success- fully overcome—cbiefly, the Directors state, by the mediym of systematic advertisement in England there seems every reason to hope for the Company's future.
TURKEY’S FINANCIAL
POSITION.
GOVERNMENT AND CONCESSION
HUNTERS.

Turkey's impecuniosity is, writes Reuter’s Constantinople correspondent, the concession bunter’s opportunity ; the greater the financial embarassments of the Government, the more soft and yielding jig. naturally becomes. Not for a long’ time has the Treasury heen in such sore straits as is at present the case. Not only are its needs and liabilities greater than usual, but its prospects of revenue are very much worse, owing to the unfortunate economic con- ditions prevailing, Furthermore, practically all available sources of extraordinary relief are already mortgaged.

At such moments, everybody who is hunting for concessions or orders comes forward with his schemes and tries to dazzle the Govern- ment with growing offers which, it is claimed, would bring relief and plenty Ao the depleted Treasury Most ofthese projects are too fun- tastic to deserve serious considerations ; others, sound in themselves, have not proper backing; finally, a few are business-like proposals, well supported, The Government is inclined to lend a sympathetic ear to any offer which seems to have money behind it, and, unfortnnately; be- lieves in the practicability of many schemes which are quite unsound and unrealigable it consequently vews its embarrassments with optimism, as it believes that it can always find reliet in these expedieuts. This thought is in some measure resporsible for the Porte’s dis- inclination to make a serious effort to disen- gage itself from the: hopeless muddle in which its fiuances are involved.
DRATH OF JUDGE BILLS.
(Gazette's Specia! Service.)
London, Tuesday.
The late Fudge Hills died yesterday at the age of seventy.
AN EXCITING VOYAGE,
SALVAGE UNDER DIFFICULT
CIRCUMSTANCES.

The British SS. “Rowa,” Captain T: B. Jones, arrived yesterday afternoon from Sweden with a cargo of timber consigtied to Mex«rs. Karam. During the voyage a large quantity of timber was washed overboard. Exciting incidents occurred during theattempts made by the crew of the “Rowa” to salvage the Danish steamer “Ulfsborg,” which she picked up 100 miles from Tyne on the 19th Ogtober, the “Ulfsborg” baving lost ber propeller. Experienc- ing the full force of a hurricane the “Ulfsborg” was rolling fearfully, haying no cargo on board. It was found impossible to launch a boat for the purpose of trensferring a hawser @» the sea was running too high Life buoys were floated from the “Rowa” with lines attached. and these were hauled on board the “Ulfsborg” and by this mean's the tow ropes were fixed. The salvage work was carried out under very ditficult circumstances indeed, owing to the rescuing vessel having a heavy list to port. The Davish steamer was successtuly brought into Tyne and handed over to a tug.

div.head: AGRICULTURE IN CYPRUS.
FRUIT AND VEGETABLE SHOW.
div.p: (From a CORRESPONDENT. )
Nicosia, Nov. 4.

The second annual Frait and Vegetable Show was beld in the Experimental Garden, Nicosia, on Thorsday the Sist October. It was a very marked success, and there can be a0 GOR that the native agripulturig wane ap appreciate this opportunity of exhibiting their own produce and seeing that of others from distant parts of the Island.

‘There were 1,141 entries for competition, which with 86 not for competitien made gp 4 total of 1,177, as compared with, we anderstand, under 200 last year. Unfortunately the bulkiof the exhibitors did net notify their-entries’ in advance, according to the directions issued, and in consequence, the work of handling the exhibits and classifying them. wee mach hamper- ed. In order not to disappoint -would he exhibitors, entries were accepted. Up . he late hour of 1'.80 on the worning of the Stidw day, but it was then absolutely netessary ’ to close the list, so astoallow timefor judging, and thus some unlucky villagers’ prodace.bad to be shat out. Exhibits were received from 56 villages, and, thanks to one exhibitor fem distant Paphos, every district in the Island was represented. The Famagusta district, in spite of her railway facilities, sent but very little. Larnaca, however, contributed some very choice specimens of corn, frait and vegetables, carefully packed in specially designed boxes. As “get up”, she certainly took the lead, which it may be hoped will be followed by others another year. Haji Halil Bl Mawy very rightly accompanied the Larnaca co signment, as it is largely due to hie work in connection with the fruit trade with Egypt that the improve- ment in grading and packing, which has taken place at that port, is due.
The above list may somewhat surprise those who are unacquainted with the extent and variety of Cyprus produce, but even this repre- sents, of course, only the produce of this season of the year.

The site chosen for the Show, suitable enough last year when’ it was on a small scale, is not adapted to the requirements of a large exhibition, such as this fixt:ire may now be regarded, and, no doubt, arrangements will be made for the use of a more extensive ground next year. Again, the Committee will prob- ably find it necessary to make it a two day affair. allowing ample time fur the reception, bandling, and judging of the exbibits.

Messrs. Francis, Pascal, Constantinides, and Perakakis acted as jodges, and an arduous task they must have fi-und it. All was ceady by 3.30 p.m. at which time the distribution of prizes was to take place, and slightly before that hour His Excellency the High Gom- wissioner and Lady King Harman arrived and made a tour of the stalls, after which His Excellency proceeded to give away the prizes,
The Municipal band played some excellent music during the afternoon.

Some interesting demonstrations were given during,the day by the Director of Agriculture in an adjuining field forthe purpose of show- ing, by the help of the dynamoaneter, the superiority of the iron over the native plough: The demonstrations, which were made in the presence of members of the press and others, showed that-not only did the iron plough per form. better work but that it imposed con- siderably less strain upon the oxen than the native wooden one.
Some agricultaral machines were op view and we hope that on future oseasions a larger number of these will be displayed and worked for the instruction of the villagers.

div.head: NOTES FROM BRYROUT
RETURN OF CONSULS GENERAL
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
Beyrout, November 7.

By the § S. “Helios” of the Austrian Lloyd arrived on Teesday last from igi Bir Ro- bert Hay Drammond-Hay, His British Ma- jesty's Consal-General, and Count Richard di Motta, Italian Qonsul-@eneral at -Beyrout. Phis moet convenient and direct menas of commenication with Europe is getting to be more and more apprecisted by the travelling public and it would be surprising, indeed, if persons boond for Syria, and not desirous or compelled to call en route at Egypt, showld not take this route. Phe Austrian Lloyd C..mpany has lately been disearding most of the old type boats and replacing them by new ones-designed for all the modern requirements of conifort and pleasant travelling.

Although the “Helios” arrived rather late at night yet Valihas been kind eupugh to mtimate to Panitary Inspector that he may pratique her. Count Di Motta, however, preferred to remain on board til! next morning but Sir Robert landed, and even at this rather late hodr ofthe night some of the Lebanese functionaries and office-seekers were there to court couselar attention and favour. Sir Robert is said to be returning home about the end of the year to.withdraw from public life and end his days quietly in a country residence he has lately fitted up in Torquay Speculation is rife abodt the probabie successor.

Ten political prisoners of whom seven. mili- tary offeers tro civil and one merghant of Naplous have lately arrived here to undergo interrogation and trial at the hands of His Excellency the Vali. These men have been brought here under escort on the strength of a denuaciatory secret report sent by a brother ofieer at Napluus to Constantivople accusing them of disloyalty and treasonable commu nigation.

div.head: DR. KOCH AND SLEEPING SICKNESS.
div.p: Professor Koch, who has returned from East Africa after a long investigation of sleeping sickness, has been interviewed by a special correspondent of the Berlin “Lokalanzeiger” regarding the result of his researches.

The Professor, who is in the best of health, told the interviewer that be had been living for the past eighteen months on a desolate island belonging to the Sesse group in the middle of Lake Victoria Nyasiza, with an army medical sergeant as his sule white companion.
They dwelt in a straw hat, and their only means of communication with the world was a primeval native boat fashioned out of a tree trunk, which conveyed them to the mainland.

Professor Koch discovered that the insect known as the Glossina Palpelis, which conveys the germs of the disease, tingads not only on the benks of the lakes, but also along the streams in the interior right up.to theiraource. Professor Koch’s remedy, says the interviewer, consisting of subcutaneous injections of arsenic, has proved efficacions, and the chief means of fighting the disease lies in constant medical attendance and in preventing patients from going into hitherto uninfected districts. To carry this out specially’ trained doctors «re necessary, and clearings must be made on rivers and lakes free from mo=quitos.

Professor Koon has ascertained that there is a distinct connection between crocodiles and sleeping sickness. Wherever crocodiles are found the disease may be discovered, but only in places near the banks. ‘The blood of croco- diles forms the chief nourishment of the glos- sina, which sucks the blood between the plates of the animal s hide. The extermination of the glossina is impossible, but the same end may be reached by destroying the crocodiles or by the removal of the bushes and undergrowth where the animals lurk.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: Tess
FOOTBALL.
SAINT ANDREW F. C,
VERSUS
ROYAL DUBLIN FUSILIERS.

This match wes played on Saturday on the Parade ground at Mustapbs. Seints won the toss and glected to kick wih te wind. From the kick-off the Dubs took ball into. Shp Saints’ territory, but Cartis saved well. Dubs continued to press and the Saints defense had A lively ten minutes. Saints had started with ten men only, and the forward line in con- sequence could not make much headway. From a breakaway, however, they forced a Corner which proved fruitless, but a few mivutes later another aa game ; and Talleeh opemed the. ing for hiasi from the requitent kick, the glancing through fram the shoulders of one of the opposing backs. Dabs retaliated strongly bat with Saints now at full strength the game opened out more. The outfield.sork of the Dubs was excellent but poor shooting at goal robbed them of the equaliser. Sueoess at last came their way from a beantiful centre from the outside right and the teams after twenty minutes play again were level. The game had new become faster than ever, both teams striving hand for the lead. Dubs were inclined to play too mueh of the close- passing game, and the Saints, on the contrary adopted the longpassing game. The letter proved the more effective, as Seinta, transferred the ball quickly frum their own god and, with a clear field, had no difficulty in beating .the bome custodian. A secdyd goal was scored by Jones and a third, five minutes later, came in similar tashion from the foot of Glark. Attwood made @ meritorious attempt to still farther increase the Saints lead, but bis shot was well taken by the custodian. Phe teams crossed over with the score Saints 3 Dube 1.

Playing down bill it was anticipated that the Dubs would give the visitors’ defence a hot time in the second half but although they pressed hard their shooting was of a very poor order. They scored their second goal in some- what lucky fashion, whet was intended for a centre by the outside right, being carried through with the wind. Dabs new looked like equalising, but Saints came away on the left, and Clark put throagh from Talloch’s esotre, thus making the score 4-2. Saints almost had a fifth goa! two minates later in exactly similar fashion, but Clark parted with the ball too early.Dubs aided by the wind were now keep- ing the Saints pretty well in their own ter- ritery but they met with astabborn defence Curtis was safe between the sticks and was ably assisted both by backs and halves. Attwood particularly shone in thia half, his head work and placing to his forwards being superb. Another lucky goal eame to the Dubs, a high centre by the right half being carried by the wind throngh the corner of upright and crossbar. Up to five mimutes from time Saints still beld the lead bat the equaliser ultimately came to Dubs and the game ended iv a draw of four goals each. The score is a pretty fairindication of the run of the play. Both teams scored three goals with the wind and one against. It was throughout a game of two games, the Doubs forwards playing scientific footbkall but failing badly at goal, and the Saints by their long passing completely outclassing the opposing defence, and taking full advantage of their opportunities. It wasa fast game thronghout, and enjoyable alike to both sides and to the many spectators who Raed: the field.

A return mateh bétween the Goldstream Guards Subalterns and the Inniskilling Dra goons Subslterns, with Capt. Nixon in place of Mr. Burvhems was pleyed at Ghezireh on Monday. This was a very interesting match to watch, the play being keen.and fast thronghout, The result was 2 goals all, The first chukker the guards scored first, Mr. Tritton making a clever shot at goal
The second period the Guards added another goal, and were 2 up before Mr. Bowen scored for the Dragoons. Third chikker Mr. Bowen scored again from a scrimmage in front of goal. 2 all.
Fourth chakker the Dragoons bad mther the best of it but were unable to seore.

For the Goards Mr. Vollemache did moat work, and M:, Tritton played well at No. I. There seemed to be a general lack of under- standing amongst the team, and Sir Walter Barttelot was much too fond of plonging into the game and meeting the bal!. A back should practically never meet the bull, unless he sees his No Sis goin k towards bis own goal. Mr. Tritton aid per his play if he rode for the back gqoner and did not wait aptil he ‘got going.” The Dragoons take too many risks, apdare inclined to try too many fepay strokes, but they play a dashing game, which A” is much marred by the unfortunate unevenness of the grounds

div.head: CARO OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: Towards the end of last month several of our contemporaries (both native and Bar ) published paragraphs dealing with an offer said to have been recently submitted to the Government by an English finance to construct at a cost of £200,000 a new Opera House in Cairo in return for certain rights and privileges to be conceded to him. In view of the interest which is certain to be taken at all our readérs in any project con- nected with the erection of a new Opera House in the Capital, to replace theantiquated structure at present dignified by that name wehave made it our business to investigate this matter and are now able to put before our readers an accurate statement of the facts of the case together with a verbatim of the offer itself, from which it will be that the murb-talked of project of bail & Hew ‘ind up to date Opera House in Cairo. From being a mere “‘on dit” is at lest likely to :hebousd an accomplished fact, provided that the Govern- ment are sufficiently alive to their own interests and to those of the community at large, both residents and nam to close at once with this exceptionally advantageous offer now before them, the terms of which are as follows :-—

“To construct, on any site provided for the purpose and to designs approved or supplied by Government, a a new Opera House, same to be handed over to Government free of all charge immediately on completion, in return for a lease, rent free or at a nominal rent, for a given term of years of the present Opera House site with full right to demolish all existing buildings ther and to erect in their stead business and other premises, the whole to revert to Government on expiration of the lease.”

The above offer, embodied in two letters addressed res rely to the Under Secretary of State for Works and to the Under Secretary of ee Ministry of Finance, was gent in, the former on the 21st and the letter on the Sist October by Mr Henry C. Moore, who has recently arrived in Cairo, and who, we understand, represents an influential group in London. ‘The result of the second letter was an invitation to Mr, Moore to attend an interview at the Ministry of Finance on thé 4th instant during which the principle features of the offer were discussed, but without any definite conclusion being arrived at.

That the existing Opera House is notably Inadequate for the purpose it serves both as regards seating accommodation for the Puclib and interior arrangement for the performers, to mention only two of its many defects is a generally conceded and much deplore fact, a fact moreover fully realized by the Government themselves who subsidize it and who have consequently for several years past considered the advisability of substituting for it one more suited to present day requirements, so much so that plans and designs for a new Opera House have been recently completed by their order and are at the -resent moment of having their consideration.

Aujourd’bui c'est l'indécision qui a prévalu Les vendeurs, en partie rassurés par l'arrét de la baisseen Europe, ont montré moins d’insis- tance. Comme résultat de cette nouvelle atti- tude, la cote s'est généralement maintenue ; elle témoigne méine d'une petite reprise par- tielle. Quant aux affaires, elles sont restées clairsemées et de peu d'importance. On est de plus en plus convainca que l’allure a venir dé pendra beaucoup de la solution plas ou moins heureuse de la crise américaine, dont |’effet le plas atténué sera *Qrement’ un drainage de nu- méraire, de nature & prolonger la disette d'or dont le marché mondial des valeurs souffre depais bientét un an. En ce qui concerne plus particulitrement notre place, od les positions restent pour la plupart surchargées et oh de fortes liquidations p sent sur le marché, on comprend l’intérét vital qu'il y a pour tous a ce ‘quela dépression s'arréte avant que les bangues ne soient obligées de procéder 4 de nouvelles exécutions, qui ne peuvent qu'aggra- ver la situation.
Sil faut en croire lee derniéres nouvelles venues de New-York les affaires seraient en voie d'amélioration que la période la plus aigiie de-la crise est passée

Une demande en National Bank a fait mon ter le cours de 19 11 16 a 19 15/16, ce qui a donné lieu 4 quelques opérations ; mais vers la fin le prix est revenu & 19 7/8, soit en defini tive une hausse de3 16 pour la matinée

L’ Agricole, la Delta Light et la Daira ont été soutenues. L/Obligation Crédit Foncier a repris de 289 4 289 1/2 l’ancienne et de 251 A 252 1/2 la nouvelle. Pour cette derniétre la chute d’hier était attribuce a l'importante vente aux en ch*res qui a eu lieu, ainsi qu’a |’annonce d'une nouvelle vente pour demain.
Plus fermes également la Cassa di Sconto qui se reléve de 40 4 40 1/2, la Banque d’A thénes de 104 & 105, et la Building Lands de 19/16 a1 11/16.

En revanche, on constate une accentuation de la baisse en Luvestment qui rétrograde de 11/32 4 5/16, Estates de 7/16 a 8 8, fondateur Comptoir de 1138/32 41 3/8, Crédit Franco Egyptien de 4 4 331/32 et Levico de 11/32 a 5/16.
Sar le reste de la cote il n’y a pas de chan gement a signaler. La moins-value de 30 francs sur les Dividendes Tramways qui s'inscri vent 4 260 s'est produite hier. Nous avions omis de la mentionner.

fl a été vendu aux enchéres publiques 100 Land Investment and Building (Fanous) a 11/82 et 100 United Land 4 15/64. A la liste des enchéres de demain, que nous publiée dans notre bulletin d’hier, il faut encore ajouter 50.actious Industrial Building and Commercial Co (Karam).

Des quelques mots que nous venons de dire se dégage la tenance du marché La spécula tion locale attend avec impatience la tournure que prendront les événements pour y confor mer sa conduite. C'est donc !’indécision et l'ex pectative qui prévalent pour le moment

De M. Jacques Siegfried, dans un article du “Temps” sur la crise américaine:

“On en est 4 la période de liquidation, qui dure plus ou moins longtemps selon que I’exa- gération en sens*contraire a été plus ou moins forte. QCepéndant la dure legon porte peu 4 peu ces fruits ; on s'est assagi, nomentanément du moins ; |’épargne se réforme et s'accumule ; les personnes qii ont été prudentes au moment des folies profitent du bon marché pour re- prendre leurs ‘achats ; la confiance renait pro gressivement et l’on reprend le cycle que je viens de décrire

“Mais dana,Ja nature des phénoméres anx- quels nous assistons, les cataclyemes qui peu vent nous atreindre nous immpressionnent d’au- tant plus que nous les connaissons moins. Lés crises étaient autrefois considérées comme des fiéanx, parce qd’elles nous surprenaient sans préparation et sans défense. Elles sont aujour-. @hui beaucoup plus connues dans leur genése, leur @volution, leur éclosion et enfin leur ter- minaison. Elles effrayent donc moins, nons trouvant mieux préparés pour les combattre, et sont sans doute destinées 4 diminuer doré- havant d’intensité.”

div.head: TELEGRAMS.
THE KAISER FOG BOUND.
ARRIVAL AT WINDSOR
div.p: London, November 11.

The Emperor and Empress of Germany on board the “Hohenzollern” have been fog bound The yacht was anchored near the Nab light ship until 11.45 this morning, when she pro ceeded on her journey. The Prince of Wales, Lord Roberts, and party are awaiting their arrival at Portsmouth. The fog is so dense that communication between Portsmouth and the Isle af Wight is entirely suspended

(Later). The German Ewperor received the heartiest welcome both at Portsmouth and at Windsor. The Prince of Wales, Lord Roberts, and the German Ambassador went on board the be-fogged “Hohenzollern” ina destroyer Tidal difficulties further delayed the landing bat the tog was momentarily lifting. The yacht entered the Barbour earlier than was expected. On hearing the royal salutes being fired the authorities, who were lunching, hastily rose and scrambled to the quay to welcome the arrival. The Emperor and Empress arrived at Windsor late: the fog was denser than ever. The King and Queen, the Duke of Connaught, and Prince Christian received them and greeted them most affectionately. Crowds cheered their arrival.
The Emperor in reply to an address said that it seemed likehome to revisit Windsor He was always glad to be here
The Empress will leave England in a tew days and will visit Queen Wilhelmina on 17th instant. ( Reuter )

div.head: THE PERSIAN BUDGET.
div.p: Teneray, November 11
Parliament has passed the budget. The deficit has been removed : the situation is im- proved. ( Reuter)

div.head: MACEDONIAN REFORMS.
div.p: MURDERS OF GREEKS.
Sofia, November 12.

The address in reply to the Speech from the Throne was presented by the Sobranye yes terday. It declares that the reforms in Mace donia up to the present have been without result and the development of Bulgaria is con sequently hindered. (Reuter )
Athens, November 12
It is stated that Bulgarians have murdered 14 Greeks at different points of Macedonia be tween the 2nd and 9th of November. ( Reuter )

div.head: DEATH OF ARMENIAN
PATRIAKCH.
div.p: Constantinople, November 12
Mkrtitch, the supreme Patriarch of the Armenians. has died at Echmiadzin. (eter)

div.head: PARIS MEDICAL FACULTY.
div.p: Paris, November 11
On account of an hostile demonstration against a recently appointed professor, the Medical Faculty has been closed until the 31st December. ( Havas )

div.head: ULLMO THE SPY.
div.p: Toulon, November 11
It is asserted that proof has been obtained that U'ilmi offered documents to Germany ( Havas )
Toulon, November 11.
There is much commotion here over 5 arrests n charges of espionage. The police have discovered a regular espionage Organisation Reuter

The newspapers say that the Imperial troops have been the reinforcements sent by Mouley Hafid to his troops. Some have. been killed ( Havas )

div.head: LORD CROMER AS HOME
ADVISER.
div.p: From the “Spectator’)

Lord Cromer took occasion on Monday to offer his countrymen some very necessary advice. It was founded on what is still recog nized as a sound maxim in business, and has until lately been supposed to bean equally sound maxim in international politics. Through out his long career, be told the distinguished company assembled at the Guildhall to witness his admission to the freedom of the City, he has derived the utmost benefit from paying exclusive attention ‘to his own business. For four-and- twenty years that business has been the creation and consolidation of Egyptian prosperity. Few people have now more than a value recollection of the obstacles which at the beginning of this period Lord Cromer had to surmount. But from one, and that the most fatal of all, he has been in a great measure relieved. Prime Ministers have come and gone, but he has remained, and he has been allowed to carry out the policy with which he started. He might have found him-elf in « very different position. He might have been instructed to change the methods and objects of his admin- istration with each change of Government at home. Had this been the case—and there has never been wanting a minority of Englishmen who would have welcomed a series of revolu tions in Egyptian policy — Lord Cromer’s po sition would bave been made impossible He might have stayed in Egypt, but he would have stayed there to no good purpose He would have ceased to represent the British Government, and would have become the representative of this or that political party. But under Parliamentary government the policy of a party cannot be continuous. It must be interrupted, or run the risk of being interrupted, at every General Election. Lord Cromer might, of course, have regarded him selfas simply the servant of each successive Foreign Secretary. But supposing that each new arrival at the Foreign Office had meant the introduction of a radical change in th. conduct of Egyptian affairs, with what show of consistency or honesty could he have set him self to undo in one five year’ all that he had done in the previous five years ' The only way out of the difficulty would have been to appoint a new British Agent in Egypt whenever there was a new Secretary of State in Downing Street. Egypt would have been governed, not for her own good and in her own interest, but for the good and in the interest of the puliti cians in power at home. Egyptian affairs would have supplied occasions fur Ministerie! defeats or Opposition victories, or fur elections i which not one elector in a thou-and would have known on what issue he was voting.

From this disastrous state of things we have saved by the tendency—happily, the growing tendency—to remove foreign affair~ from the acute stage of party discussion. In France this end was attained for a long time by the continuous presence at the Foreigi Office of the same Minister Parties had their torn, minorities became majorities, but M Delcassé. held his post in one Government after have discovered a better, because a surer, road to the same end Our Foreign Minister has changed with each change of Government, but our foreign policy has remained the same. Lord Salisbury and Lord Granville, Lord Rosebery and Lord Landsome, have entered office and left it, and Sir Edward Grey reigna in their stead, but successive Governments have steadily Labored to carry out the same ideas, It is This that has made continuity of policy possible In Egypt, and thus secured the first condition of Egyptian prosperity. It might have been thought- that, with the splendid results of Lord Cromer’s policy full in view, and with the connexion between these results and the con- tinnity of his purpose equally visible, there been no need for him to give his countrymen the advice contained in his speech at the Guildhall. It would have been enough. fér him to point to Egypt now and to Egypt a quarter of a century ago and to draw the moral for ourselves But quite recently a new way of looking at Foreign affairs , and our own policy in regard to them, has appear in this country, and ap- Seared in a quarter in which it might have Been thought least likely to find a footing. For More than two generation the permanent un- known quantity in our foreign policy was our With other Powers our relations were sometimes friendly and some- times hostile; with Russia they were always more or less hostile. Nos this condition of

permanent ill will has come to an end. The Convention with France, which bas taken a whole series of possible difficulties out of the way of both countries, and given our position in Egypt what is virtually equivalent toe European sanction, has been followed by a Convention with Russia. A settlement which British Governments have been dreaming of for more than half-a-century has actually been arranged. We are left at peace upon our Indian frontier, and it we have had to make some concessions in Persia, it has only been because there are two sides to every bargain, and something bas always to be given in return for something got. That a few advocates of an extreme anti-Russian po'icy should have been willing to forego every con- ceivable advantage in Afghanistan, rather than yield a fraction of influence on the Persian Gulf, was only to be expected. The habits of a lifetime are not laid aside without annoyance and difficulty. But it is not in this section of the public that the opposition to the Anglo- Russian Agreement has chiefly shown itself. The objection, strange to say, has come from the antimilitarist group, from the men whose desire for peace is not proof against their dislike of the Powers with which until now we have been most likely to find ourselves at war. The Labour Party, or some of them, would have contendly seen this risk prolonged, and possibly made permanent, rather than ac- quiesce in the establishment of better relations with a Government whose internal policy they dislike. So long as that internal policy remains unchanged, they wish to subject Russia to a apecies of diplomatic boycott They do not stop to consider which party would be the worse sufferer by such a boycott. It is enough for them that Russia is badly governed, and so must be left to give us all the annoyance that can be caused by an unfriendly neighbor at any part of a long frontier, line.

It is at this point that Lord Cromer comes in with his severe common-sense. Englishmen, he says, have the reputation of being very free with their advice to foreign countries. “Foreigners are apt to think that there are a good many affairs nearer home that might profitably occupy our attention,” but not with- standing this we have a'ways some time and thought to spare for the affairs of our neigh- hours. Now, so long as this disposition goes no further than the Press no great harm is done Englishmen are accustomed to speak their minds freely about what is going on abroad, and they do not limit their attention to matters with which they may be supposed to have some acquaintance. Foreign Governments must know this pretty well by this time, ind they have probably learned not to pay much attention to it. But if this feeling were to be extended from newspaper articles or seasonal speeches to the actual policy of Great Britain, if our Government were to be prevented from concluding advantageous ['treaties because Englishmen do not like the domestic policy of the Power with whom the Agreement is to be made—and there are ‘certain politicians who would willingly push their convictions to this extreme—we should be applying to politics a rule which we never dream of applying to ordinary business. A firm does not refuse to make a contract with an- other firm because one of the partners is believed to have behaved harshly to a son who had run into debt, or another is suspect ed of not getting on well with hi« wife. These, we feel, are private and domestic matters with which are not concerned Families must settle their own quarrels, and outsiders have neither the knowledge necessary for in- terfering wisely, nor the right to interfere at all. In nation has about as good a Government as it is fit for, and has not, it is quite certain that we should meet with neither success nor gra titude if we tried to give it a better one “The Russians,” as Lord Cromer truly says, ‘must be left to work out their own political salvation.” But that they are doing this after their own fashion is no reason for neglecting our own interests where they come in conflict with theirs. The “more conventional method of allowing British interests to form the basis of diplomatic action abroad, to the exclusion as far as possible of all extraneous ind irrelevant matter,” is still the only method which appeals to commonsense, and if we were to look at the question from a purely Ruasian point of view, we should arrive at an identical Would the constitution of the Duma be made more democratic, or the action of the bureaucracy less harsh, by hostilities upon the Indo-Russian frontier! Is it not more like that the necessity of sending troops into the field and the patriotism evoked by a war with a European Power would only put the Russian revolution further off! If the op- ponents of the Anglo-Russian Convention had had their way, no one would have been the better for their success except, it may be, the contractors for the supply of munitions of war in both countries. This is the success which we should have attained it we had elected to mind other people's business instead of our own,—a success which would have been equally dis astrous to ourselves and to those we imagined ourselves to be serving.

div.head: COTTON IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Alexandria correspondent of the “Man- chester Guardian” writing on October 27, say that “Egypt is probably beholden to the priority of her own financial crisis for the fact that events in America have caused no appreciable disturbance in the value other cotton. There have been oscillations during the week, and on the eve of the American collapse prices had mounted to T.20 5-82 on revived talk of a damaged and shrunken crop, but on balance the week closes with a drop of T.9/16. Its to be remembered that Egyptian cotton is no double the value of American. This would not be very unusual were the Egyptian crop fully disposed of, overran three quarters of it, bu there appears to be no good authority for th statements in print alleging that the crop i: sold to that extent. Striking the average of ac cepted estimates it is doubtful whether mach more than two-fifths of the or :p has been placed up to the present. There is no acceleration iv exports either; on the contrary, the week's shipments did not exceed 25,200 bales, against! 80,000 last year. A steady flow of business, nevertheless, continues in the spot market. The bidding at the Domains suction on Thursday is a good index of the prices readily realised for choice produce. 3,500 canters o Afifi in nine lots were sold to Messrs. Choremi Benachi and Co., Mr. N. G. Casulli, and the Anglo-Egyptian Bank at an average of T. 19 9/16, whille 1,915 cantars of white Joannovich fetched in seven lots an average ot T. 24 5/16. Fifteen Afifi bales and 21 Joannovich balés o Scarto cotton were also put up to auction, and were satisfactorily disposed of Dealings have multiplied during the week in November, 1908, which now stands at 5 16 above the current November. Not only are the probabilities of partially exhausted irrigation in the coming spring sustaining the November, 1908, quota tion, but likewise the high price of wheat, for if its present and rising value of 128 piastres theardeb lasts, wheat should besown upon nach land that is now forced to bear cotton year after year.”
